awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Investigating Illegal Dumping During the Course of Debris Collection Operations Following Hurricane Ian
awd_abstract_narration:
Hurricane Ian made landfall as a catastrophic Category 4 hurricane on September 28, 2022, in the southwestern region of Florida. It generated substantial amounts of debris, exceeding the capacity of local waste management systems. Delayed collection of debris from public property and rights-of-way incurs public health and safety concerns. Since affected communities use their own limited resources for debris removal before the reimbursement by FEMA, it is critical to accurately estimate and keep track of the uncollected debris throughout recovery. While various tools are available to estimate the initial amount of disaster debris, current approaches do not update the estimates as a debris collection process proceeds over time. Further, illegal dumping - the disposal of ineligible debris at public sites without legal permission - often causes such initial estimates to become obsolete and complicates debris logistics planning and reimbursement management. This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project aims to collect ephemeral data on uncollected debris on public roadways during the course of debris collection operations in order to investigate illegal debris disposal and its social and environmental impacts. 

This project will (i) conduct a sequential survey of affected public roadways with unmanned aerial vehicles and a LiDAR scanner to capture the amount of illegally dumped waste over time, (ii) link illegally dumped debris to its relevant collection trajectories through collaboration with debris contractors, and (iii) perform online surveys to understand the social and environmental impacts of uncollected debris, debris disposal methods, and community settings. The volume of debris at different points in time will be quantified through machine learning algorithms with aerial imagery and 3-D point cloud data resulting from the sequential survey. The volume of illegally disposed debris on each roadway section will then be estimated by comparing the debris volumes at subsequent times along with the volume of debris collected by haulers over the elapsed time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: RIDER - Resilient Infrastructure & Disaster Response Center

por.por_cntn:
Illegal debris dumping (i.e., disaster-generated debris disposed of in unauthorized locations or outside of the required time window for federal reimbursement) is one of major challenges during debris cleanup efforts in post-disaster conditions. In response to federally declared major disaster events, federal recovery funds are available for affected communities to remove those debris in a timely manner. The debris placed on curbside placed after the time window for federal reimbursement often limits the effectiveness of post-disaster recovery funds and often lead to delayed collection of debris. These behaviors can hinder recovery operations, pose environmental and public health risks, and strain limited resources. Most existing studies on illegal dumping focus on normal conditions, overlooking the complexities and urgency of post-disaster scenarios. By investigating illegal dumping in the context of a disaster, this project aims to provide insights into why these behaviors occur. To fill this knowledge gap, this project aimed to collect ephemeral data on uncollected debris on public roads to better understand illegal dumping behaviors during disaster recovery operations.

To achieve this goal, three field investigations were conducted in Florida, targeting areas with significant debris accumulation—specifically, the cities of North Port and Arcadia. The investigations took place in November 2022, December 2022, and January 2023, allowing for observing changes in debris over time. The data collection methods included the use of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) for aerial surveys, 3-D LiDAR scanners to capture detailed measurements of debris volumes, and collaboration with debris contractors to gather debris hauling data. These methods provided comprehensive insights into both the quantity and locations of debris. In addition to field data, an online survey was distributed to residents to understand socioeconomic factors that might influence illegal dumping behaviors. The project estimated illegal debris by comparing field data with reported debris collection records.

The findings of this study reveal significant differences between the volumes of debris reported by contractors and those observed during field investigations. The calculated amount of illegally dumped debris is notably large, primarily due to the high turnover of debris on the streets between successive field investigations. Contractors continuously collect debris, resulting in high reported volumes that significantly exceed the static volumes captured during periodic field assessments. Moreover, the volume of debris collected by contractors often includes legally placed debris by residents. The challenge of differentiating between legal and illegal debris inflates the estimated volume of illegally dumped debris. Additionally, planned three field investigations are limited in capturing all fluctuations in debris volumes, leading to further overestimation. This indicates a need for a more refined field investigation to accurately track and categorize debris.

To address these challenges, increasing the frequency of field investigations is crucial. The most accurate results would be obtained by conducting a field investigation before each debris collection mission within each area. However, to make this approach practical and feasible, an automated system utilizing aerial imagery to estimate debris volumes is recommended. Such a system would provide continuous, real-time data, ensuring more precise tracking of debris addition and removal. By integrating advanced imaging technology, we can enhance the accuracy of debris volume estimates and better distinguish between legal and illegal debris, ultimately improving the efficiency and effectiveness of debris management operations.

The research revealed several technical, demographic, and environmental factors contribute to this behavior, including insufficient individual awareness of debris handling, lack of proper waste disposal facilities, employment conditions, and the overwhelming volume of debris generated after disasters. By studying these behaviors in various communities across Florida, the project developed a clearer picture of why and where illegal dumping is likely to occur. This understanding is crucial for local governments and agencies as it allows them to better anticipate illegal dumping and take steps to prevent it during future disaster recovery efforts.

One of the outcomes of the project was the creation of a unified database that integrates various types of data, including socioeconomic factors, and debris volumes. This database will serve as a valuable tool for researchers and government agencies, enabling them to analyze illegal dumping patterns and identify areas most vulnerable to this issue. By understanding these patterns, authorities can develop better strategies for managing debris in future disasters.


Last Modified: 09/17/2024
Modified by: Juyeong Choi
